entry.name: Abiotic
entry.desc: a non-living factor in an environment i e. light, water, temperature

entry.name: Adaptation
entry.desc: the long term process of evolutionary change by a species

entry.name: Aestivation
entry.desc: dormancy, generally seasonally

entry.name: Alien species
entry.desc: species that arenot native (natural) to an area are also known as non-native species, introduced species, non-indigenous species, exotic species and invasive species.

entry.name: Altricial
entry.desc: young birds that are born naked and with eyes closed, unable to leave the nest

entry.name: Aquatic
entry.desc: growing, living in or frequenting water

entry.name: Arboreal
entry.desc: tree dweller

entry.name: Autotroph
entry.desc: an organism capable of manufacturing its own food by synthesis of inorganic materials, as in photosynthesis

entry.name: Bergman’s rule
entry.desc: among forms of a particular species, body size tends to be larger in the cooler regions of its range and smaller in the warmer regions

entry.name: Bioaccumulation
entry.desc: the additive accumulation of substances in the tissues of organisms in food chains

entry.name: Biomass
entry.desc: the total mass of all biological organisms

entry.name: Biotic factors
entry.desc: living organisms that impact the growth, composition, and structure of the forest (e.g., insects, herbivores, humans)

entry.name: Brood
entry.desc: the offspring of a bird just hatched

entry.name: Browse
entry.desc: (v) to eat the twigs and leaves of woody plants; (n) commonly used in wildlife management to signify brushy plants utilized by deer

entry.name: Buteo
entry.desc: any of the various hawks of the genus Buteo, characterized by broad wings and broad, rounded tails

entry.name: Critical Habitat
entry.desc: geographic area containing physical or biological features essential to the conservation of a listed species or an area that may require special management considerations or protection

entry.name: Carapace
entry.desc: the upper or dorsal surface of a turtle’s shell

entry.name: Carnivore
entry.desc: an animal belonging to the order Carnivora, including predominantly meat eating mammals

entry.name: Carrion
entry.desc: the bodies of dead animals usually found in nature in a decaying state

entry.name: Carrying capacity
entry.desc: the number of wildlife species that a given unit of habitat will support without damage to the habitat

entry.name: Cast
entry.desc: to regurgitate indigestible prey remains

entry.name: Circadian
entry.desc: designating a biological period of about 24 hours

entry.name: Climax stage
entry.desc: the final stage of plant succession

entry.name: Clutch
entry.desc: total number of eggs laid by a female bird in one nest attempt

entry.name: Commensal
entry.desc: a term to describe a species that lives in close association and gets some benefit from another species but does not return any benefit (e.g. gopher frogs live in gopher tortoise burrows but provide no benefit for the gopher tortoise)

entry.name: Consumptive use
entry.desc: any use that involves activity resulting in the loss of wildlife i.e. hunting

entry.name: Contour feather
entry.desc: predominate feather type found on the body, wings, and tail of the bird

entry.name: Contiguous forests
entry.desc: forests that share an edge or boundary

entry.name: Coverts
entry.desc: one or more of a group of feathers covering the bases of the longer main feathers of a bird’s wings or tail

entry.name: Covey
entry.desc: a small group or flock, often a family group, of birds such as quail

entry.name: Crepuscular
entry.desc: appearing or becoming active at twilight or dawn

entry.name: Clutch
entry.desc: eggs laid and incubated by a female bird per nesting

entry.name: Corridor
entry.desc: areas of continuous habitat that permit animals to travel securely from one habitat to another

entry.name: Crepuscular
entry.desc: active at twilight, dawn, and dusk

entry.name: Dabbling ducks
entry.desc: duck species that principally feed in shallow water by “tipping up” or dabbling on the surface

entry.name: Depredation
entry.desc: the act of preying upon in reference to wildlife damage to farmer’s crops

entry.name: Disease vector
entry.desc: Vectors are vehicles by which infections are transmitted from one host to another. Most commonly known vectors consist of arthropods, domestic animals or mammals that assist in transmitting parasitic organisms to humans or other mammals.

entry.name: Diurnal
entry.desc: a term used to describe an animal that is most active by day

entry.name: Dorsal
entry.desc: of or pertaining to the upper surface

entry.name: Dump nest
entry.desc: eggs deposited by more than one female in a single nest

entry.name: Ecosystem
entry.desc: a community of organisms and their physical environment interacting as a unit

entry.name: Edge
entry.desc: the place where two or more different plant communities come together or meet

entry.name: Endangered
entry.desc: species in danger of extinction or extirpation if the harmful factors affecting their populations continue to operate (compare with lesser risk categories of threatened or species of special concern)

entry.name: Endemic
entry.desc: confined to a certain area or region

entry.name: Estivation
entry.desc: a state of inactivity during prolonged periods of drought or high temperatures

entry.name: Extirpate
entry.desc: elimination of a species from a given area; local extinction

entry.name: Feral
entry.desc: domesticated animals that have gone wild (e.g. hogs, dogs, cats)

entry.name: Fledge
entry.desc: the act of leaving the nest or nest cavity after reaching a certain stage of maturity

entry.name: Flyway
entry.desc: fly routes established by migratory birds

entry.name: Food chain
entry.desc: a sequence of feeding types, on successive levels within a community through which energy and biomass is transferred (e.g. plants are eaten by rodents that are eaten by snakes that are eaten by hawks)

entry.name: Food Web
entry.desc: a network of food chains by which energy and nutrients are passed on from one species of living organisms to another

entry.name: Forage
entry.desc: vegetation taken naturally by herbivorous animals (n); the act of searching for and eating vegetative materials (v)

entry.name: Forest Game
entry.desc: game species that are managed by the DNR whose habitat needs are found mainly in forests

entry.name: Fossorial
entry.desc: a burrowing mammal having limbs adapted for digging

entry.name: Furbearers
entry.desc: various animals that have a thick coat of soft hair covering their bodies

entry.name: Gene pool
entry.desc: the total genetic information that a population has or the sum of all genes

entry.name: Guard hairs
entry.desc: long, coarse hairs that forms a protective coating over an animal’s under fur

entry.name: Habitat
entry.desc: the place or environment where an animal (or plant) naturally or normally lives and raises young

entry.name: Habitat Conservation Plan
entry.desc: A plan which outlines the impact of a listed species living within a project area, the steps taken to mitigate the project's impacts and the funding that will be available to implement these measures, alternatives to the project and why they were not adopted, and any other measures that the Fish and Wildlife Service has determined to be necessary for the plan.

entry.name: Harvest
entry.desc: proportion or number of a wildlife population brought to bag by hunters

entry.name: Hatch
entry.desc: to emerge from an egg, pupa, or chrysalis

entry.name: Herbivore
entry.desc: an animal that eats plants

entry.name: Herpetology
entry.desc: the scientific study of reptiles and amphibians as a branch of Zoology

entry.name: Heterotrophic
entry.desc: requires organic compounds of carbon and nitrogen for nourishment; 'most animals are heterotrophic'

entry.name: Hibernation
entry.desc: the act of passing all or part of winter in a dormant state where body functions is greatly slowed

entry.name: Incubation
entry.desc: the act of rearing and hatching eggs by the warmth of the body

entry.name: Indigenous
entry.desc: a naturally occurring species

entry.name: Insectivore
entry.desc: a mammal or organism that feeds on insects

entry.name: Invertebrate
entry.desc: lacking a spinal column

entry.name: Keystone species
entry.desc: a species that other species depend upon for survival

entry.name: Larvae
entry.desc: the immature, wingless, and often wormlike stage of a metamorphic insect that hatches from the egg, alters chiefly in size while passing through several molts, and is finally transformed into a pupa or chrysalis from which the adult emerges

entry.name: Lateral
entry.desc: pertaining to the side

entry.name: Limiting factor
entry.desc: Anything affecting the population of a species which could result from causes in nature as well as human activities. Examples include food, water, shelter, space, disease, predation, climatic conditions, pollution, hunting, poaching and accidents

entry.name: Litter
entry.desc: the number of young born with each birthing

entry.name: Mandibles
entry.desc: either the upper or lower part of the beak in birds

entry.name: Marsupial
entry.desc: a mammal of the order Marsupialia that includes kangaroos, opossums, bandicoots and wombats. These females have pouches that contain mammary glands and that shelter the young until fully developed

entry.name: Melanistic
entry.desc: abnormally dark pigmentation of the skin or other tissues

entry.name: Migration
entry.desc: the movement of animals to and from feeding or reproductive and nesting areas

entry.name: Molt
entry.desc: to shed hair, feathers, shell, horns or an outer layer periodically

entry.name: Monogamous
entry.desc: term used when one male breeds with one female

entry.name: Mortality (death-rate)
entry.desc: the number of animals that die each year

entry.name: Natality (birth-rate)
entry.desc: ability of a population to increase; reproductive rate

entry.name: Nestling
entry.desc: a young bird that has not left, or abandoned, the nest

entry.name: Niche
entry.desc: that part of a habitat particularly suited to the requirements of a given species

entry.name: Nocturnal
entry.desc: active by night; the opposite of diurnal

entry.name: Omnivore
entry.desc: an animal or organism that feeds on both animal and plant matter

entry.name: Ornithology
entry.desc: The scientific study of birds as a branch of zoology

entry.name: Pair bond
entry.desc: the association between two birds who have come together for reproduction; can be short-term (lasting only through egg-laying or the rearing of young) or lifelong

entry.name: Parasite
entry.desc: an organism that lives by deriving benefit (usually doing harm) from another organism

entry.name: Passerine
entry.desc: birds of the order Passeriformes, which include perching birds and songbirds such as the jays, blackbirds, finches, warblers and sparrows

entry.name: Pelage
entry.desc: the hair, fur, wool or other soft covering of a mammal

entry.name: Philopatry
entry.desc: annual homing to the same nesting area and often the same nest site

entry.name: Plastron
entry.desc: the ventral surface of the shell of a turtle or tortoise

entry.name: Polygamy or polygyny
entry.desc: term used when a male animal breeds with many females

entry.name: Population
entry.desc: the number of a particular species in a defined area

entry.name: Population dynamics
entry.desc: factors regulating population levels including natality, productivity and mortality

entry.name: Precocial
entry.desc: young that are capable of a high degree of independent activity from birth

entry.name: Range
entry.desc: the geographic area or areas normally inhabited by a species

entry.name: Rare
entry.desc: species that are uncommon, and usually potentially at risk because of their restricted geographic area or habitat.

entry.name: Riparian area
entry.desc: the area of influence between upland habitats and aquatic habitats

entry.name: Ruminant
entry.desc: an even-toed hoofed mammal with a stomach of four chambers that swallows its food un-chewed, then regurgitates it, chews it thoroughly, and re-swallows it. Common ruminants are the camel, giraffe, deer, pronghorn, and cattle

entry.name: Scat
entry.desc: the excrement droppings of an animal

entry.name: Species
entry.desc: populations of animals that possess common characteristics and freely inter-breed in nature and produce fertile offspring

entry.name: Species richness
entry.desc: the number of wildlife species found in a given area

entry.name: Species of Special Concern
entry.desc: Species that are considered vulnerable to large-scale population declines. This category is not as severe as endangered or threatened.

entry.name: Taxonomy
entry.desc: the arrangement of plants and animals into groups based on their natural relationships. Standard classifications are into 7 groups listed below, but are subdivided for different taxa

entry.name: Kingdom
entry.desc: the two dominant kingdoms are plant and animal.

entry.name: Phylum
entry.desc: vertebrates and invertebrates are the most recognized phyla.

entry.name: Class
entry.desc: vertebrate classes include birds, mammals, fish, amphibians, and retiles, there are multitudes of invertebrate classes, and fish often are broken into many classes.

entry.name: Family
entry.desc: examples of families in the order carnivore include Canidae (dogs,wolves) Felidae (cats), Musteidae (weasels, skunks, badger), and others.

entry.name: Genus
entry.desc: the genus of dogs is Canis (genus names are always capitalizedand either underlined or italicized).

entry.name: Species
entry.desc: closely related individuals which actually or potentially interbreed, the domestic dog species is familiaris, the coyote is latrans, and the wolf is rufus, all in the genus Canis. Species names are underlined or italicized, but NOT capitalized.

entry.name: Terrestrial
entry.desc: living or growing on land

entry.name: Territory
entry.desc: The concept of dominance over a unit of habitat; an area defended by an animal against others of the same species, or sometimes other species; can be defended for breeding, feeding, courtship, or other reasons.

entry.name: Threatened
entry.desc: A designation given to species that are likely to become endangered in the foreseeable future if current trends continue. This is the intermediate category between endangered and species of special concern.

entry.name: Toxin
entry.desc: any of various poisonous substances produced by certain plant or animal cells

entry.name: Upland game
entry.desc: game species that are managed by the DNR whose habitat needs are usually found in upland areas

entry.name: Trophic level
entry.desc: a feeding level in the food chain of an ecosystem characterized by organisms that occupy a similar functional position in the ecosystem

entry.name: Ventral
entry.desc: of or pertaining to the lower surface

entry.name: Waterfowl
entry.desc: water birds, usually referring to ducks, geese and swans
